Review title: Die Hard 2 is my all time personal favorite Action film an underrated
Review_body: Die Hard 2 in my opinion is my third favorite decent action flick in a "Die Hard" series and a good movie to watch. It is one of my personal favorite action movies. It is one of the most underrated "Die Hard" films in the series and that not a bad one. His wife again a hostage, Christmas again, the same reporter from the 1st film, now a janitor Marvin is a helper instead of Argyle and so on. As far as sequels go, Die Hard 2 is excellent. Of course it isn't better than the first, but sequels rarely are. This film is like going to a circus: you sit back and watch crazy stuff happen, laugh, cheer, joke, and just have a good time. Bruce Willis gives a great performance in the lead, we have some solid villains, and some brilliant action set pieces. I say check it out. I'm not one to subtract points for a lack of realism, or "real world believability" in films. Because of that, Die Hard 2 poses a very interesting case study for me. Real world believability is very difficult to not think about when watching this film. Why wouldn't the planes just reroute to other nearby airports? There are a bunch less than an hour's flight away, including Baltimore, Philadelphia, the three New York City-area airports, and so on. Why wouldn't they be able to call another close airport, or the Pentagon, or somewhere else nearby to have them contact the planes? They're near Washington, D.C., after all (don't forget that Dulles is 26 miles away from D.C., in Virginia, making it unlikely that planes out of fuel would begin "dropping on the White House lawn"). It seems like maybe this film should have been set somewhere like Salt Lake City, Utah instead. Why wouldn't they be able to show the runways through some other means, like a line of emergency or police vehicles with their sirens on? If the "terrorists" started shooting at the vehicles, or trying to blow them up, at least they'd be given an indication where the fire is coming from/given their location. Just how likely would it be that there's a big storm in the area on the day when General Ramon Esperanza (Franco Nero) is being extradited? How likely is it that he'd be extradited on Christmas Eve? Why the hell is John standing out on the runway in the snow waving a couple of flaming poles--just what does he think that will do? Die Hard 2 is still awesome movie and sequel to the first one for me and I don't know why people are saying it is the worst one or why they hate it. I don't, I love it, more than the first one I love it. In 2005 was my first best action movie than the first one. What I love about this film is they show John McClain more as a human being. In the beginning at the airport when his car was taken away at the airport, the whole movie show's an actual terror the villains are more of a threat cause they're actual terrorists! The Action sequences are awesome, there is barely any Cgi in it, John McClane is again in another elevator shafts. I love the plot twist that was wonderful, the snow in the film, the mobile snow chase whit McClane was awesome. This film is not perfect It is good, it has some problems in it. Always enjoyed watching it. The problems for the airport I already mentioned, the most annoying to me was after McClane kills the henchman when he was saving Leslie Barnes he pushed a terrorist of the latter and that latter tower falls on a terrorist you can see that it is a dummy from close that should not been seen from close camera.It is still It is one of my personal favorite action movies mostly in the winter when it is snowing. The first movie was hug success, Renny Harlin's job by making this movie make it even harder for him, to find a good story, and make a snow because they didn't had any actual snow at the time it was really hard. I love it. The facts I love: Chase with the Snowmobile, shooting with blanks on Carmine Lorenzo, fights on an airplane, double cross, John's jokes... The General Esperanza on airplane from Val Verde the same country was named in Schwarzenegger's movie Commando, John's shooting with snowmobile, than John's fight by the church. Movie to me is really awesome. I enjoy watching Die Hard 2. 10/10 Grade: Bad-Ass Seal Of Approval It is my second favorite Die Hard film in the series.

Review title: An efficient action film that fulfills its purpose thanks to the moments of impact, the engaging plot and, above all, its captivating main character
Review_body:
The first film became one of the great classics of action cinema. After the huge success of "Die hard", Bruce Willis stars in this sequel directed by Renny Harlin, who bets on the charisma of his character and in a new unusual situation to create scenes of strong impact. Perhaps weakened by the clearly less scary villains than Alan Rickman's clever Hans Gruber, "Die Hard 2", achieves a result that is inferior to the first film, but still pleasant.In this sequence, after taking control of Washington airport, a group led by Colonel Stuart (William Sadler) awaits the arrival of Colonel Esperanza (Franco Nero), a political prisoner who is being extradited, and threatens to bring down aircraft if the police do not follow your requirements. The problem is that Holly (Bonnie Bedelia), the wife of John McClane (Bruce Willis), finds himself on one of the planes and he will do everything possible to save his wife.As in the first film, the plot of "Die Hard 2" takes place at Christmas and places John McClane involuntarily in the middle of a high-risk situation. Written by Steven E. De Souza and Doug Richardson, based on a book by Walter Wagner, the script this time centralizes actions at Washington airport, using the same elements that were successful in the previous feature, such as at-risk wife Holly, the police playing against McClane and the sensationalist and unscrupulous press that, this time, prepare a live broadcast of the plane, interested only in the audience and without caring about the lives that are at stake.Correctly, the script dispenses with the presentation of the characters and their motivations (not least because many are known to the viewer) and goes to conflicts, making the narrative go live once Colonel Stuart (Willian Sadler), informs the rules to the controllers from the airport. Aided by the editing of Stuart Baird and Robert A. Ferretti, director Renny Harlin fluently alternates between the plots and allows the viewer to follow Holly's drama on the plane, the work of the police and McClane and the close monitoring of the villains from within of a church. In fact, the moment when John discovers the church where Stuart runs the airport illustrates the work of the assemblers, alternating between plans at an intense and never confusing pace.For those who saw the first film, there is not much news in Die hard 2. Willis is the policeman who mistrusts, investigates and is inside everything, while the others either do not believe in McClane or just hinder him instead of helping. The villains are not as interesting as in the previous film, but they have some surprises. Detail for the early appearances of John Leguizamo and Robert Patrick, making goons of the main villain, and the small, but convincing, participations of Franco Nero and John Amos. As violent as any good example of action cinema in the late 1980s / early 1990s, the intention of the filmmakers to blame the dangers for which John McClane lives in this sequence, as well as to maximize the threat of terrorists, is striking. In a United States after 9/11, it would be unimaginable to run a script like Die hard 2, in which villains take over an entire airport and take thousands of people hostage inside the planes that arrived there. For those who, in 1990, believed that that script was an exaggerated fiction, history ended up showing us that nothing is so violent that it cannot be real.Renny Harlin's driving towards the direction makes the narrative engaging and quite tense. Much of this tension is also due to the fact that "Hard to Kill 2" addresses a collective fear when involving airplanes, since most people identify with the drama of passengers and panic with them when problems start to arise. The director still does well in conducting great scenes, such as the impressive sequence of the landing and explosion of the Windsor 114 airplane, in which the spectacular visual effects also stand out. After this scene in which the hero cannot avoid the tragedy, the viewer fears for the future of the characters, because now the villains have already proved what they are capable of. For this reason, after the landing of General Esperanza, the tension dominates the canvas and is only relieved when John is ejected from the plane, in an exaggerated and unrealistic moment that, on the other hand, is of a praiseworthy plastic beauty that only illustrates the good director's work.
When the actions leave the airport, not even the frantic sequences in the church and in the forest prevent the high tension load from dissipating, thanks to the end of the feeling of closure present in the first film and in a good part of the second, reducing the impact of narrative. Still, the sequence in which John chases the bad guys in the forest is interesting, sliding only in the moments when the villains repeatedly shoot at close range. The narrative also presents a great turnaround when the army reveals its partnership with Stuart, maintaining its breakneck pace and returning panic to the airport when the villains try to escape with General Esperanza.Photography bets again on dark tones and night scenes, reflecting the anguish of the protagonist, in addition to increasing the tension in the audience through natural elements such as snow and night. Therefore, when the lights go out and all the controls disappear, chaos takes over the place and the viewer feels part of that environment in despair. Obviously, the excellent sound effects contribute to this ambience, standing out especially in the shootings and explosions, as well as the soundtrack of Michael Kamen injects adrenaline with his loud chords. And finally, the realism and graphic violence of some scenes makes us believe even more in what we see on the screen, such as when a man has his throat cut and when one of the villains is sucked by the turbine of an airplane.John McClane remains adorably sulky, but this time he appears less vulnerable than before, perhaps due to the excess of scenes in which he literally does the impossible to escape death. On the other hand, Willis is very well in these scenes, which require enormous physical effort, in addition to maintaining the character's charisma, essential to win over the viewer and make him cheer for him. The actor still maintains great empathy with Officer Powell, played by Reginald VelJohnson, and his constant concern for his wife helps to humanize the character - and Willis has merit in this too, making us believe that he does indeed fear Holly's death. Among McClane's enemies, Colonel Stuart of William Sadler is a respectable villain, even though he doesn't have the strength of Alan Rickman's Hans in "Die Hard". And it is also worth mentioning Major Grant, played by John Amos, who initially empathizes with McClane thanks to his direct way, immediately taking action and leaving the theory of bureaucratic captain Lorenzo (Dennis Franz) aside, but this empathy would reveal itself ironic and treacherous.However, some sequences are exaggerated. The scene that most reflects this is when John, already in the final climax of the plot, uses the helicopter of the press itself to reach the plane with the villains and, after being dropped on the wing of the Boeing, face the enemies. This unimaginable situation results in a fight between the hero and Stuart, who inexplicably prefers to leave the aircraft in motion and face him, instead of accelerating the plane and taking off, forcing McClane's inevitable crash. After that, John falls off the wing of the moving Boeing after opening the fuel tank and manages to blow it up, in an exaggerated scene that closes the narrative. And it is precisely these exaggerations that compromise part of "Die hard 2". Still, the features of the feature make up for these shortcomings. In the last scene, a police officer plays a joke on John's ticket that opened the film, bringing comic relief at the right time and ending the narrative well.The plot slips when trying to present something bigger than the first film, involving more characters and inserting them in a story with greater proportions. Despite this, McClane remains the savior of situations, such as avoiding a plane crash at an airport with no lights moving around an airstrip with two torches in hand. The dose of adrenaline in the story is doubled and shows the first signs of a poetic license about the character who, before, was as human as possible. Here, the policeman becomes the only one capable of restoring peace and suffers much more than before, leaving himself more invincible, even though the action scenes themselves do not lose their style.Die Hard 2 does not live up to its predecessor, even if it increases the scope of the threat. Although Bruce Willis has more space for his cute things in this sequel, this copy ended up being much less fun. With scenes more forced and less realistic than in the first film, this second episode of the series is an efficient action film that fulfills its purpose thanks to the moments of impact, the engaging plot and, above all, its captivating main character, who literally carries the narrative on his back.

Review title: A monumental sequel
Review_body: A year after the Nakatomi incident in the first film, John McClane is now an L.A. cop and he is expecting to meet his wife at Dulles Airport. Unfortunately for him, this Christmas isn't going to get merry with out getting bloody first - a team of mercenaries who plan to free a high profile prisoner, also soon to arrive, seize control of the airport and threaten to start crashing planes if their orders aren't followed. Too bad for them that John McClane is there to give 'em hell.The monumental first film in the now classic series seemed impossible to top, and as far most people see it, that's the truth. This film doesn't in anyway top the original, but it's a great sequel. Bruce Willis does a great job at reprising his tough as nails, wise-cracking hero and a new director, Renny Harlin, really pushes him to new limits. Unfortunately that also means that a lot of logic is lost - or rather in this case, blown up. The original's plot was very clever and almost believable as a good thriller not just as a very entertaining action film and that is where this film falls short of its predecessor. The set-up, while very good by action movie standards and provides a very entertaining film, is just a little dumb in parts. The script could have been refined a little before shooting to get that cleverness back that made the first one so good.However, this film is in no way a let down. The bad guys are a ruthless bunch that you'll love to hate (especially William Sadler), there are a few twists along the way that make very entertaining, and Renny Harlin's action scenes are pretty intense all the way through. 8/10Rated R for strong violence and profanity

Review title: What's the problem ? It's a great sequel
Review_body: *SPOILERS*SPOILERS*SPOILERS*SPOILERS*SPOILERS*SPOILERS I don't understand the complains about "Die hard 2 : Die harder" . The first movie was almost a perfect action movie . It was obvious that sequel will be weaker , yet "Die hard 2" is a very satisfying sequel . It follows the formula that worked so well the first time : one hero - one place - many terrorists , wife in danger , nobody listens to him except a black guy and everything happens during Christmas . There is not a bit of new idea here . The only change is the new director – Renny Harlin , who took over John McTiernan (who was busy with "The hunt for Red October") . Harlin is a solid craftsman and he directs the movie professionally. The screenplay was once again written by Steven Souza and with a help from Doug Richardson.I'm amazed by the complains about the violence and swearing . Look people , this is R rated movie . If you can't stand the heat , stay out of kitchen. Maybe people who are obsessed with political correctness forgot about it , but in REAL LIFE people swear . A lot. And there isn't a single scene of unnecessary violence here . When you're fighting for life you don't exactly have time for subtlety. If you're looking for mindless violence watch one of those stupid "Saw" movies. And for god's sake there is no plot hole with the planes . You want to know why the airplanes didn't tried to land on other airports ? Because they had too little fuel and the weather was too bad. So , they had to stay in the air.What I liked ? Bruce Willis is back as the wise cracking John McClane . So is Bonnie Bedelia as his wife. Reginald Veljohnson appears in a small episode as Al Powell. There are one dimensional , but fun characters : John Amos as the idiotic chef of airport security Carmine Lorenzo and Tom Bover as Marvin the wacky janitor. Souza has a sense of humor and there is a plenty of moments to laugh . The action scenes directed by Harlin are exciting and fun. The screenplay offers also some nice twists.What I didn't liked ? I could live without the naked tai chi . There is one scene with the grenades that makes my head hurt. Those have to be the slowest grenades in the movie history. I don't understand why the airport crew cooperated with the terrorists , even after the terrorists lost their equipment and couldn't blackmail the airport anymore. Also , the movie lacks a really good main villain compared to Alan Rickman from "Die hard" or Jeremy Irons from "Die hard 3".Anyway , it's a good continuation of McClane's story . There is nothing new here , but it's well executed. In the end it's one of those rare satisfying sequels. I give it 8/10.

Review title: Stale action
Review_body: This review contains spoilers.Die Hard 2 is an action thriller movie that premiered in 1990. The movie is the second installment and sequel to 1998's Die Hard. The movie features John McClane with Bruce Willis reprising his role. Terrorists have taken over Washington Dulles International Airport and John McClane must deal with the developing situation.Die Hard 2 is a sequel that tries to match its freshness of the original. However this is not successful. Die Hard 2 has a new setting with an airport but the same tropes and cliches apply in this movie. John McClane is caught off guard by terrorists that seize the airport. He must deal with the terrorists as the cops form a perimeter. In addition, the sequel feels much more muddled than the original. There are not many stand out moments in this sequel that would make it exciting to watch.I would not recommend "Die Hard 2".Grade: D.

Review title: Die Harder--And More Violently
Review_body: The 1988 action thriller DIE HARD was such a huge critical, commercial, and artistic success that it was probably inevitable, given Hollywood's mentality that there is never too much of a good thing, that a sequel would follow.  The result, thus, is DIE HARD 2.Bruce Willis returns as John McClane, who on this Christmas Eve is at Dulles International Airport in Washington awaiting the arrival of his wife (Bonnie Bedelia) from Los Angeles.  Flights, however, are being delayed all across the board into D.C. by one of the biggest blizzards on record.  And when Willis spots Army mercenaries in sensitive areas of the airport where nobody is supposed to go, his cop instincts take hold.  As it turns out, these mercenaries are led by a hard-nosed right-wing colonel (William Sadler) whose aim is to snatch a known Latin-American drug dealer (Franco Nero) from the hands of U.S. justice agents.  Their reason, as Sadler puts it, is because he had "the guts to stand up against Communist aggression."  To prove his point, Sadler and his minions shut the entire airport down, putting all those planes in the snowbound skies over the nation's capital in mortal peril, until Nero's military plane arrives.  The result is a battle in more ways than one, as Willis must not only tangle with Sadler's gang, but also with an incompetent airport cop (Dennis Franz) who thinks Willis is a lunatic.Very solid acting from Willis, as well as Fred Dalton Thompson and Art Evans, who portray the two sympathetic airport officials, helps DIE HARD 2 remain leagues ahead of the majority of testosterone-laden action flicks. But many of the same flaws that were in DIE HARD 1 creep up here again.  To paint the airport cops as incompetent buffoons just so that Willis can be the hero of the piece is grossly inaccurate and offensive.  Even the media, in the guise of the ultra-obnoxious Dick Thornberg (William Atherton), gets slammed, and not in a very fair or accurate fashion.  And the violence and language in DIE HARD 2 are far more pervasive than the original, with at least two scenes (the icepick to the eye; and Sadler's ex-commander [John Amos] getting sucked into the engine of the getaway 747 at the end) approaching extreme in terms of bloodshed, and the use of the 'F' word approaching SCARFACE in terms of occasions when it is used.Still, there is plenty of suspense and tension to be had here, with the direction of Renny Harlin evincing, at times, the feel of a Spielberg or Peckinpah at their edge-of-the-seat best.  Michael Kamen's score, which interpolates Jean Sibelius' "Finlandia" at the end, is also a plus.The verdict is that DIE HARD 2: DIE HARDER is not an unflawed film, but one can certainly do much worse.

Review title: In retrospect, rather tiresome
Review_body: Bruce Willis doesn't get on well with Christmas in Die Hard, so we have obvious grounds for a sequel.  Set at Dallas Airport, Willis has to try and overcome some terrorists who are threatening to let planes drop from the sky - including the one bringing his wife home.This is everything that was Hollywood in the 80s [despite this being made in 1990], action, big explosions, gun fights and not a lot else.  Any semblance of a plot is out of the window -- although that's not why you watch these films is it?In comparison to the other great sequels of the time, the Lethal Weapon films, this really does look aged and haggard.  The Lethal Weapon series at least moved on, and developed the characters well as they got older and moved with the times.Credit must go to Dennis Franz, who might as well have been called Officer Stereotype.  How an actor could be so desparate as to play possibly the most one dimensional character in film history, one can always wonder.Watch it when having a few beers on a Saturday night.  Preferrably about a dozen of them.

Review title: It's also a Christmas film
Review_body: It's actually a very good sequel, but at the same time, it couldn't live up to the original film, and it's of no surprise because the original film is probably the greatest action film of all time. Most would agree. Still, "Die Hard 2" is right up there among the best action films of the nineties (Die Hard was made in the eighties), and everyone knows that the nineties was the time where action films dominated the cinema screens mainly due to the success of "Die Hard". What I enjoyed about "Die Hard 2" is that it was set inside an airport, and the airport is large and full of people. It's also very busy. Everything, in the movie, happened so fast. Someone like John McClane was moving and jumping everywhere throughout the airport. He has to fight with a lot of people. The setting is totally different compared to "Die Hard" which was set inside a tall building or skyscraper. John McClane has a bigger challenge in this sequel. I like how "Die Hard 2" tries to be different. In fact, it was a success! That's why you won't find "Die Hard 2" boring. There was plenty of action and explosion. The main villain in "Die Hard 2" was a guy named Colonel William Stuart. I disagree with a lot of people that he wasn't a good villain. Colonel Stuart was the reason "Die Hard 2" was entertaining. I like him. I just like how different he is compared to the villain in "Die Hard". He knows who John McClane is. He heard the story in LA where John McClane defeated a bunch of terrorists. I like that moment where Colonel Stuart figures out that John McClane happens to be in the airport. That was one of the best and fine moments of the movie. I also liked the fight between the two at the end. Colonel William Stuart is an underrated character in the Die Hard series. He was played by a well-known actor. Some of the cast from the first film, Die Hard, were in this sequel such as John McClane's wife. There was also that reporter - I don't like him. "Die Hard 2" is an "action" and "thriller" film. That's two of the most popular film genres. "Die Hard 2" will also "surprise" you. You have to see the movie to understand what I mean by that. There's a twist to the story. What I liked the most about "Die Hard 2" is that pretty much everyone knows who John McClane is after his heroics in LA. "Die Hard 2" also happens to be a Christmas film just like "Die Hard". The events happen to take place on Christmas Eve. Just be sure to add the film to your Christmas watchlist!

This movie is full with action sequences and many plot twists as it should be. Bruce Willis amazes again with his character, skills and attitude. Review title: John McClane is back with a bang!
Review_body: Die Hard 2 is the sequel to the fabolous action-movie Die Hard 1. John McTiernan refused to direct the sequel to his blockbuster, so it was up to Renny Harlin to direct Die Hard 2:Die Harder. John McLane is at Dulles Airport waiting for his wife, and as usual something goes terribly wrong. A South-American dictator has been arrested, and it just so happens that he is going by plane to Dulles Airport. The dictator has many followers in the US, and terrorists blackmail the airport. They demand that the dictator is given a new plane when his plane has landed. Once again, it is up to McLane to save the day and his wife! The action is once again mostly flawless, and every bit as good as the original. 10/10
